Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 07:36AM ehall wrote: Hi Liz--I'm 15 months post BM and still get achiness in left arm (BC side and SNB).  Today I saw my PT whom I haven't seen in months...she thinks its still part of the healing--I recently had scar revisions and nipple reconstruction.  She said surg. can cause scar tissue which as it heals can bind to nerves and cause achiness. She also said weather can cause achiness.  She recommends stretching and taught me some massages to the scar areas.  I don't have any swelling--and I exercise & stretch like crazy--so I'm fairly convinced its not LE.  But like so many of us--I keep a close eye on it.  Did you get your sleeve and glove--any relief?  Erin
Posts.Title: Achy arm econmom ehall

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 06:45PM ehall wrote: I too was allowed to shower 48 hours after surgery.  I tied the shoe string around my waist, fastened my drains with safety pins, and stood in the warm shower until the water turned cold--it was heaven!
Posts.Title: showering with drains HeatherL PhyllisCC

Posts.Title: just found out! tammyj38 Kerry71

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 04:38PM - edited May 21, 2008 04:43PM by ehall
Posts.Title: just found out! tammyj38 Kerry71

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 04:37PM ehall wrote: Hi there--I was too was diagnosed with the same at age 46 in September 07.  I sought out 3 breast care specialists with varying opinions.  I gathered all the facts, sought out women in similiar circumtances, and most, importantly, outlined my goals.  In a nutshell, I wanted lowest possible reoccurance/risk, symmentry and best cosmetic outcome, no treatments that would compromise or risk future risk (ex:  radiation would limit options if a future mastectomy had to be done due to reoccurence), and peace of mind.  I also consulted with several plastic surgeons.  To make a long story short--I did exhaustive research and ultimately decided on a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction through the latissmis dorso procedure.  Its been a along 8 months...but one I have never regretted.  My best advice--get a second opinion, do your research on the options, and don't panic.  Feel free to contact me via email for anything.... swanhall@bellsouth.net   Erin
Posts.Title: just found out! tammyj38 Kerry71

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 04:38PM - edited May 21, 2008 04:44PM by ehall

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 04:38PM ehall wrote: Hi there--I was too was diagnosed with the same at age 46 in September 07.  I sought out 3 breast care specialists with varying opinions.  I gathered all the facts, sought out women in similiar circumtances, and most, importantly, outlined my goals.  In a nutshell, I wanted lowest possible reoccurance/risk, symmentry and best cosmetic outcome, no treatments that would compromise or risk future risk (ex:  radiation would limit options if a future mastectomy had to be done due to reoccurence), and peace of mind.  I also consulted with several plastic surgeons.  To make a long story short--I did exhaustive research and ultimately decided on a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction through the latissmis dorso procedure.  Its been a along 8 months...but one I have never regretted.  My best advice--get a second opinion, do your research on the options, and don't panic.  Feel free to contact me via email for anything.... swanhall@bellsouth.net   Erin
Posts.Title: just found out! tammyj38 Kerry71

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 07:23AM ehall wrote: Hi Laura--I had a bilateral mast. last Sept. and am 7 weeks out from my expander exchange.  Initially, my implants were flat & round--kinda hamburger bun look.  But now they're full and have great projection.  I had 800 cc in my expanders and received 700 cc high profile silicone implants.  I'm very happy....been to the beach, a cruise, pool, etc.  My sixteen year old is even wowed by how they look!   After the exchange--it does take 3-4 weeks for them to fill out aka "fluff".  No pics...still pondering the idea of posting them.  Hope this helps.  Erin
Posts.Title: After bi-lat and expanders Estepp danix5

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2008 07:52PM ehall wrote: The size issue was frustrating--since there is no real "recipe".  It depends on body size, chest width, etc. Generally 200-230 ccs equal a cup size--but its very general. What I did find was that my dr. perferred to overexpand to ensure a natural droop.  I also found that my implants were smaller than the expanders...800 ccs to 700 cc implants.  Aside from the obivious decrease in cc--the implants are softer and projection is somewhat less from the expanders.  If you really desire a B cup....make sure your dr. knows and ask him/her to help you achieve that.  Good luck! Erin
Posts.Title: After bi-lat and expanders Estepp danix5

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 06:56PM ehall wrote: Hi Renee--I'm one year out from my bilateral mast. and have no regrets.  The toughest part was weighing my options and chosing the right one for me.  I spent 8 weeks agonizing, crying, and researching--I consulted local drs. and out-of-town well known teaching hospitals.  Once I made the decision--I felt like I could move (a little) forward recognizing it was only the first step. There were some dark moments--especially immediately following my surgery.  But with time--my mind and body healed.  Today--I look and feel great!  Its a tough decision but only one that you can make.  Best wishes....Erin
Posts.Title: Should I have a full mastectomy? BooBee kjcsis

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 09:05PM - edited Jun 2, 2008 09:05PM by ehall
Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy-your input wanted tweekerbeeker lilith

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 09:05PM ehall wrote: Hi there---I too opted for a pmast last september due to mutifocal high grade DCIS in left breast.  Lots of factors went into my decision....getting rid of cancer--minimizing lowest posisible risk of reoccurence, fear, symmetry, and beyond.  I have no regrets....and very happy with where I am.  Had expander exchange 3 weeks ago today....healthy, exercising, walking 5 miles a day, and love my new ta ta's.  I will share...that it's a process and one that you need to go into knowing about---there are some low moments and risks with any major surgery.  Do your research, ask lots of questions, and ultimately make the decision that YOU are most comfortbale with. Good luck--Erin
Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy-your input wanted tweekerbeeker lilith

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 05:31PM ehall wrote: Stacey--I was dx last fall with dcis in left breast.  For a host of reasons and after consulting 3 drs.which included an evaluation of my pathology report, age, peace of mind, symmetry, etc.--I too chose to have a prophylactic bilateral mast. and have not looked back.  I am almost 6 weeks from having my perm implants placed and am doing very well. Let me first assure you that this is a very personal decision that is both medical and emotional.  Gather all the facts, do your research, and then decide.  There are federal laws that require insurance companies to pay for reconstruction choices for the unhealthy and healthy breast--to include symmetry such as implants, lifts, or prophylactic mast.   Hope this is helpful--take care.  Erin
Posts.Title: Options stacymo pinoideae

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2008 06:12AM ehall wrote: Hi there--my bilateral mast. incision was circular around my areola. Once I have my nipples and tattoos...it will be concealed. My SNB scar is about 3 inches and somewhat under the arm on the side of my breast--not very noticeable.  I had tightness but it subsided after a couple of months...lots of stretching seemed to help best.  Best wishes--Erin
Posts.Title: bilateral incisions--which way is best? harmonysun otter

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 05:43PM ehall wrote: Hi Keryl--1 month after my bm last fall my dad was dx with AML leukemia.  The was a healthy 71 year man who just returned from a 3-week hunting trip up north.  He had no known health problems--very active--physically and mentally.  Sadly, less than 9 weeks later he passed away from this very agressive form leukemia.  I sit here and write this with tears welling up.  My dad was my soul mate and there are so many nights that I lay in bed and just think about him.  I go to his grave at the National Cemetery and just sob.  My mom is still with us but so consumed with loss...its almost as though she is not with us.  I find comfort in doing something that was very important to him.  He was just finishing a manuscript on the first attache to China for Princeton University.  The Editor who he had been corresponding with for the past 2 years came to Atlanta to view his work.  She became so excited and insisted that we the family (aka me)....finish it.  Its an honor to finish my dad's work--knowing it was very important to him.  It does help to make the emptiness subside--at least for a few hours.  Erin
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 04:21AM ehall wrote: Good morning--I too had pain and was referred to a PT who specializes in working with BC patients.  I am 13 months from my BM--and am in better shape today and almost pain free (just a few lingering twinges).  The PT was to able quickly help me regain my range of motion (no more hunching over and walking stiff armed).  She was also great at massaging the areas that gave me nerve pain and a heavy fullness feeling.  She was quickly able to get to lay flat on my back (I was sleeping in a recliner with lots of pillows)--a temproary relief.    I would recommend asking your PS for a referral--definitely someone who works with BC patients.   Wishing you a speedy recovery--Erin
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy/Lumpectomy Pain Syndrome mom2two sueUK

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 07:22AM ehall wrote: Wow--had no idea they still made tube tops--haven't seen or wore one in 20+ years :-)  I loved the sports bras from Target.  I also wore a cami as well.  I think its just a personal perference--go with what's most comfortable for you.  Good luck--Erin
Posts.Title: Tube Tops Verses Sports Bras SheriVery Roberta77

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 01:19PM ehall wrote: Hi there--I didn't ask how far they were in...until they came out.  My advice....close your eyes and count to 3 and they'll be gone.  And yes...enjoy the freedom and another step forward :-)
Posts.Title: drain removal Elliemae32 sam408

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 05:59PM ehall wrote: Hi Lisajo--I too was dx with dcis last summer.  I did my research and knew that although time was on my side--I would not be satisfied until I sought out another professional opinion...for both peace of mind and medical reasons.   Hope this helps--Erin
Posts.Title: Does DCIS cause pain? lisajo Beesie

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 03:53PM ehall wrote: My PS recommended sports bras.  Target and Walmart have the best selection...soft with just the right amount of support.  Erin
Posts.Title: Most comfortable bra for expanders? rayhope soccermom96

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 10:07AM ehall wrote: Hi Nicole--sorry you're facing this at such an early age.  If there's a silver lining--its the fabulous cosmetic reconstructive options you have.  At 46 I had a bilateral mastecomy and am just finishing my reconstruction.  I too have met so many women who want to "show & tell" and their recontructions are amazing.  Talk with several PS and see what type of reconstructive options they will offer you and don't forget to ask to see pictures.  Take care....
Posts.Title: don't want to lose my nipple... help me Nicole22 tamc130

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 03:40AM ehall wrote: Same for me but took them for 10 days.
Posts.Title: after surgery antibiotics Andy17 samiam40

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 06:38AM ehall wrote: Hey Kendra--you're not alone!  There are so many emotions that come with BC--how we feel about ourselves, how our mates see us, anxiety, sadness, 2nd quessing our choices, and the list goes on!  Through the first weeks and even months after being dx (June-August)--I couldn't imagine being initimate with my hubby.  It took all my energy just to get through the day and then I would spend my evenings researching & crying.  My entire world was consumed with BC.  One thing that helped was a week-long cruise we planned a week before my surgery. It helped us to relax and the passion was incrediable!  After surgery--my hubby was extremely supportive--draining tubes, making dinner, and more.  Lingerie will help especially while you have TEs.  You'll also be amazed at how you'll compensate in other ways :-).  BC is a journey and it will take time for your world to return to the new normal!  Best wishes--Erin
Posts.Title: having bilateral mx December 4th klml4 Issymom

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 10:01PM ehall wrote: Hi there--its the simple pleasures that keep us going :-)  I had a pedicure a few days before and wore toe nail polish.  I also put moisturizer on my face with very light foundation. No one said a word....and I felt great!   Erin
Posts.Title: Can I wear toenail polish to surgery? BustersMom jdg1

Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 05:15PM ehall wrote: Don't forget a clean shoe string to tie around your waist and safety pin your drains too.  You'll never have to worry if they're attached to your clothes and accidently "jar" them when you go to the bathroom or get changed (yup...day 2..I clipped them to the tops of my boxer shorts--imagine my surprise when I went to the bathroom--OUCH!)  It also keeps them close---and over the first few weeks...you will have a love/hate relationship with them. Erin
Posts.Title: My surgical tips/tricks nancyh lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 08:52PM ehall wrote: Good morning--our local hospital has a Women's Center.  The gift shop at the Center accepts  gently used donated bras and protheisis.  Maybe one in your area has the same?
Posts.Title: prothesis qhlady2000 ehall

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 02:52AM ehall wrote: Hey there--I dont believe its anthing unusual to have sporadic drainage for a day or so.  I remember when I had my last drain after 3 weeks and just knew that my ps would take it out the next morning.  But as "murphy's law" would have it--that little bugger drained over 40 ccs the next day!  And it stayed in for a little longer.  Stay in touch with your dr and dont be surprise if it starts flowing again.  Erin
Posts.Title: Drain not draining dixie46 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 01:08AM ehall wrote: Hi Route53--I can remember 1 year ago--it took me 10 days to take a peek.  Every time I got in the shower or dressed--I deliberately turned away from the mirror.  It just so happened that my 16 year caught me one day and said "you haven't looked, have you?".  Of course, I put on the brave mommy look and said "no--I'm really not ready".  She said "ok then--we'll do it together--turn around and on the count of 3 you drop your towel and I'll raise my shirt".  I couldn't help but giggle.  So on the count of 3--we bared it all!  It wasn't long before we were laughing and crying all at the same time.  Stay positive and know that when you're done...your breasts will look nothing like they do today.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Getting your first peek after Skin Sparing Mastectomy Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 01:45AM ehall wrote: I understand you can get a cami at the ACS for free....just go to their website for contact info.  I also wore silky cami's that I picked up at Target.  They were light, loose, comfortable, and inexpensive.  As for your drains--I tied a show string around my waist and safety pinned them to it.  I then did worry about them getting hung up on clothes.  Hope this helps...
Posts.Title: camisole or bra? jmfl robin711

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 08:13PM ehall wrote: I had the same numbness and a very full feeling--and some weird sensations that would shoot down my arm.  This lasted for about a year.  At about 6 months I got a referral to a PT who really helped with massages and range of motion exercises.  Today a year later--the numbness and fullness is gone.  I still favor the arm--if I am lugging a suitcase through the airport or carrying bags at the mall.  Other than that--all is well.  A PT might be worth a try. If you decide too--make sure its one who specializes in working with BC patients.  Best wishes--Erin
Posts.Title: Numbness in Arm After Surgery DENTHOMAS pinkmama

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 11:10PM ehall wrote: Hi there--for me it's made all the difference in the world.  I had my nipples done in November and am very glad I close to do so. Truth be known I haven't worn a bra since then.  I invested in INC camis at Macys...they're thin, light, and not restrictive and provide all the support and coverage I need (I have 700 cc implants too).  I wear lots of shell''s (sleeveless fitted shirts under suits) and have great coverage.  I have a hint of a nipple--but nothing overly noticeable.  I'm having my tattoos done on May 16th and con't wait to get all this behind me....Erin
Posts.Title: To nipple or not to nipple? Linda-L sbmolee

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2008 09:41AM ehall wrote: Hi there--I was where you are this time last year.  The decision making process is a terribly painful process.  I share many of Jan's sentiments and feelings...and opted for a bilateral mast. last fall.  I've never regretted my decision for a moment.  I can only wish you well and reassure you.  Good luck and many hugs are being sent your way--Erin
Posts.Title: Need to decide one breast or two? catemarie catemarie

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 09:02PM ehall wrote: Hi Julie--my hubby was at home with me for the first week--had bm with immediate reconstruction.  But after a couple of days--he could leave me for a 2-3 hours and I was fine. I also had lots of family & friends coming in & out with food. You'll sleep and rest alot.  Most of the assistance you need is with your drains--depending on your gag level.  You'll also need assistance with showers...I placed a portable toilet in the shower and would sit and let the warm water run over me...it was heaven!  I recommend zip or buttom up jammies...you won't feeling like pulling anythign over your head.  Hope this helps--Erin
Posts.Title: How long will I need FT help at home after surgery? BustersMom Nice_Nichols

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 08:24AM ehall wrote: The pathology report typically comes back about 5-7 days after surgery.  I was able to brush my teeth.  My PS allowed me to shower 2 days after my surgery.  The nurses in the hospital were great in helping me (I was in the hospital for 4 days).  I recommend a chair in the shower.  What worked great was a portable potty that we had from years ago.  It's light weight, had side rails, and easy wipe down.  You'll probably also have drains....the best thing that worked for me was to tie a long show lace around my waist and safety pin them to it.  It kept them secure, they didn't dangle, and with clothes on--you didn't have to worry about them geeting tangled in your clothes.  Yes--your PS and nurse should share lots of stuff with you....but I would encourage you to draw up a list of questions.  There are lots of places to get questions you should ask before, during, and after your mast.  Carry the list with you--you'll be amazed at how many questions you'll come up with in any given day.  Best wishes--Erin
Posts.Title: Questions about After Bilateral Mastectomy hlya lifegoeson

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 06:37AM ehall wrote: The waiting is the worse.  I had a biospy last June and confirmed BC is left breast.  The best thing I did was seek out 3 medical opinions from 3 breast care surgeons in Atlanta.  I also consulted with drs. from Sloan Kettering in NYC (have a family member who was able to pave the way for me).  Whatever happens....you can handle it...just arm yourself with facts and options and disregard personal opinions.  Once you know the facts and prioritize what's important to you---you'll do what's right. I know its sometimes hard to find a silver lining...but if its BC--know that you have lots of options and its your call as to what you want to do.  Take the time to weigh out your options....I waited almost 8 weeks before I opted for a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  No regrets, peace of mind--cancer gone, lowest risk of reoccurence, no remainign treatments, and outstanding cosmetic outcome. While you're waiting...do your research and ask lots of questions.  God bless....
Posts.Title: nervous about surgeon tomorrow tonya24 ehall

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 07:51PM ehall wrote: Hi there--I too had a BM with expanders in September.  I was still very uncomfortable and had drains at 2 weeks.  About 3-4 weeks--I started PT with a breast specialist--the increased range of motion and changes she made in my sleeping positions was a huge step forward.  She was able to get me out of the recliner and on my back--flat.  I felt much better.  I would suggest asking your PS for a referral.  Hope you're feeling better very soon--take care. Erin
Posts.Title: recovery time Young79 karen34

Posts.Content: May 26, 2008 08:44PM ehall wrote: Hi Anne--I just had my exchange 2 weeks ago tomorrow.  For a year I've looked forward to that day.  I was amazed to discover how emotional it was for me for 2-3 days. I had a sense of loss...more than when I had my bilateral mastecomy--and felt some sense of disappointment.  I had such high expectations but kept looking down at what looked like hamburger buns and thinking will they ever look like breasts!  Now 2 weeks later--my new girls are looking fabulous and I'm feeling much better.  My golden nugget to you...the process continues..be patience.  Good luck and take care...
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 12:27PM ehall wrote: Hi there--Binney is definitely very knowledgable and I would only echo her advise.  My biggest fear is that I'll develop LE and I do everything she recommends--especially hyrdrate, massage, exercise, and never schelp suitcases.  My PT recommended that I not wear a sleeve/glove/or wrap--unless I develop LE.  The rationale was that the compression could agravate.  I fly 2-3 times a month and have been since 16 months after my surgery.  Knock on wood--I've not had any problems. Best wishes...Erin
Posts.Title: Afraid To Fly Artemis mumito

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2018 10:18PM ehall wrote: Hi there—I had surgery on December 28th to remove what was left of my tumor. Should note my BC was a reoccurrence after 10 years and bilateral mast in 2007. Am HER2+. I also had invasion in pec muscle and chest wall. Surgeon was able to to get clean margins and other than a few cells around nerve endings—all is well. Surgery was the easiest part of my treatment protocol. Started chemo in August 2017 and expected to continue until August 2018 with just perjeta and Herceptin. Will begin 40 rounds of radiation the week after next and then Femara March 1st for 5 years. Fingers crossed that my reconstruction will survive. Hoping for no further surgeries. Took awhile to get my head wrapped around my new normal. But so far managing through it all. Take care
Posts.Title: Tumor Invading Pectoral Muscle - surgical concerns AgathaNYC jo6359

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 07:17AM ehall wrote: Hi Allie-I've been seeing a PT every couple of weeks...she does lots of stretching (angels in the snow without snow, reaching stretches) and reflexability work.  She has also showed me some light weight exercises using 3-5 lbs...pull-ups, fly aways, pec work (the worse).  I've been traveling lots and make sure I always regularly exercise.  I've never worn a sleeve or been fitted for one.  I recognize there is a lifetime risk...good luck!  Erin
Posts.Title: I am flying this week,uh oh lymphedema? skigrl kira

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 01:59PM ehall wrote: Hi Tamina--you're in a great place for support.  Definitely ask lots of questions and know that its a process.  Keep reminding yourself that you're saying goodby to cancer and hello to life!  There are lots of us who have been where you are...you're in all our thoughts...take care--Erin
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2008 08:02AM ehall wrote: Hi Donna--waiting for test results is one of the toughest periods.  Most of us...thought we knew everything about breast cancer--given the amount of information available and heightened awareness through the media.  I very quickly realized how little I actually knew 9 months ago.  My head seemed to be in the dizzying swirl of information and advice and my body was in panic mode! Stay busy with your sister, do some preliminary research--not too much until you're sure what the dr. says--it will only overwhelm you.  And definitely write down all your questions you have for your doctor.  No question is insignificant! We're all keeping good thoughts....Erin
Posts.Title: waiting, waiting, and more waiting Emily2008 yellowrose

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 08:02PM ehall wrote: Your emotions are all normal.  The weeks leading up to surgery were my worst moments (had bilateral mastecomy in September and last week had my expanders exchanged).  Stay calm and know that everythign you feel is normal.  The best advice.....trust your doctors and have no doubts in your mind about their medical opinions and abilities.  And don't hesitate to ask every question you have.  I have drove my doctors nuts since September....even calling nurses and making a friend out of the office manager who faced BC 2 years ago.  If you're married, have kids, belong to clubs, or involved in your community--don't be afraid to share how you feel.  Reach out and those who have faced it too (and lord knows there are many)--will reach back to you. God speed....you're in our thoughts and hearts.
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 07:59PM ehall wrote: Hi Carollyn--the party sounds great.  Your positive attitude is a definite plus!  I remember being with a friend a month ago who had one of her breast removed...the nurse asked her to mark it...and she handed me the pen.  Knowing my friend's healthy frame of mind...I wrote "bye, bye boobie".  We laughed and then cried...but it was all good.  As for being home by Friday--you might be able too.  But don't push it...nows the time to really pamper yourself and get lots of rest. We'll be thinking of you.  Let us know how you're doing when you get home.  Hugs--Erin
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 07:24AM ehall wrote: Hi there--I too had a SNB a year ago September.  Since May I've been flying monthly and sometimes more often--with no problems.  My PT gave me lots of exercises--and I do them religiously.  Of course, I always know there's a risk....Good luck--Erin
Posts.Title: I am flying this week,uh oh lymphedema? skigrl kira

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 06:39AM ehall wrote: Hi Libby--I would not have been able to endure or enjoy the trip at 4 weeks.  Although you might have other conflicts--have you considered rescheduling your surgery until the week after your trip to ensure you're up to it and min. the risk of any complications?  Although I;m no dr.--BC is pretty slow growing and I'm not sure delaying by 4-5 weeks would really matter.   BTW--surg. are used to changes for all sorts of reasons...so don't let their schedule hold you back :-).  I even rescheduled one of my reconstructive surg. 1 week out.  Good luck--Erin
Posts.Title: How did you feel 4 weeks post bilat mastectomy? libby sbmolee

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 08:14PM ehall wrote: Hi Sherry--I kinda had a similiar experience with my expander.  After 4 weeks of expansions--a red hot spot about the size of a large ping pong ball appeared--there was not pain--just red and warm.  I was put on Keflex and other oral antibiotics.  After 3 weeks--I also received a pic line (even though dr. and infectious disease dr. said it would likely have to be removed).  They threw an arsenal of antibiotics at me at the infusion center twice a day for weeks.  Unfortunately, nothing worked and my expander had to be removed.  6 weeks later it was replaced and to make a long stroy short--I am 4 weeks from my expander exchange and everything is going very well.  Best of luck to you--Erin
Posts.Title: Right Foob is red MsSherry MsSherry

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2008 05:01PM ehall wrote: You'll find that many of us have used all kinds of tricks to hide the little buggers.  I tied a shoe lace around my waist and safety pinned my drains to it.  I only did this after I pinned them to my shirt and accidently took my shirt off and forgot they were pinned.  Very close call :-).  It was also great when I had to shower...the shoe lace dries in about 30 minutes.  Good luck!  Erin
Posts.Title: How large do tops need to be to accommodate drains? rayhope Dawnmrn1

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 08:28PM ehall wrote: Ditto on the PT and light massage.  It will get better...but it will take time.  Best wishes...Erin
Posts.Title: skin sensitivity - help? rseaw22 rseaw22

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 01:23PM ehall wrote: Oh do I know your disappointment.  I had the same happen 4 1/2 weeks after my surgery last fall.  They threw the arsenal of antibiotics at me--I even had a pic line and went to an infusion center for 3 weeks.  My expander was removed and I had to wait 6 weeks for it to be reinserted...and then another 8 weeks to catch up with my fills. Medically I was and still am fine....emotionally I was a wreck!  I'm sure you've heard this...but hang in there and be patience.  Today--I'm 11 months post bilateral mast. with reconstruction.  My exchange was in May and I'm awaiting nipple reconstruction next month.  In retrospect--the time went quickly.  Best wishes--Erin
Posts.Title: Removal of Tissue Expander due to Infection csifinski Kinclan

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 09:00PM ehall wrote: Hi Rio--welcome home!  Now is the time to pamper yourself and let your body & mind heal.  Time has a wonderful way of taking care of us.  I'm 11 months from my bilateral mast & reconstruction--and doing just fine.  You too will be the same in the coming months.  Take care--Erin
Posts.Title: Feelings before surgery Rio ehall

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 08:10PM ehall wrote: Hi Sherry--after all we've been through it really doesn't seem fair.  I know you're down--I was there too in December.  The drs. inserted a pic line and threw the arsenal of antibiotics at me for 3 weeks...nothing worked and my expander had to be removed.  I was an absolute basket case--crying and on the verge of hysterical meltdowns every day in the infusion center.  My stomach was a mess...and my emotional stability was at best fragile.  I swear the nurses would draw straws to see who would have to treat me that day :-) I finally looked around at lots of others who were in far worse shape and reconciled myself that 6-8 weeks after my expander came out it would be re-inserted.  Today I am 4 weeks post-implant and doing very well.  I share this because I know where you're at right now and it's very discouraging.  Hang in there and know that you will move beyond this point.  Huge hugs!  Erin
Posts.Title: Right Foob is red MsSherry MsSherry

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 07:00PM ehall wrote: Yup...hubby needs to understand that this is about you & your needs...and if it helps to share--then so be it.  Tell your sweetie that it may not be what he would do....but it's something you need right now to help you weather this new path in life. I'm sure he is as frightened as you are...my husband sure was.  It might even help for him to share it....he'll be surprised how many of his buddies and colleagues have been touched by BC in their families.
Posts.Title: Husband doesn't want me tell tell anyone! robyn33 roseg

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 01:42PM ehall wrote: Rayhope--I would call my PS and make sure he/she says its ok to start exercising.  As with everythign else--all PS have their preferences as to when its best.  I too got a referral to a PT who has been incrediable.  She helped to establish some baselines for me and got me back in better shape then when I started.  Good luck!  Erin

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 06:48PM ehall wrote: Sometimes the drain tube around the skin can get irritated.  If dr is ok with it...I wouldn't worry.  Hang in there--once they're gone...you'll be so relieved...
Posts.Title: Help with drains califsun otter

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 06:38AM ehall wrote: The waiting is the worse.  I had a biospy last June and confirmed BC is left breast.  The best thing I did was seek out 3 medical opinions from 3 breast care surgeons in Atlanta.  I also consulted with drs. from Sloan Kettering in NYC (have a family member who was able to pave the way for me).  Whatever happens....you can handle it...just arm yourself with facts and options and disregard personal opinions.  Once you know the facts and prioritize what's important to you---you'll do what's right. I know its sometimes hard to find a silver lining...but if its BC--know that you have lots of options and its your call as to what you want to do.  Take the time to weigh out your options....I waited almost 8 weeks before I opted for a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  No regrets, peace of mind--cancer gone, lowest risk of reoccurence, no remainign treatments, and outstanding cosmetic outcome. While you're waiting...do your research and ask lots of questions.  God bless....

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2008 10:10PM ehall wrote: Hi there--I too had one where the stitch seemed to come loose.  When I mentioned..my ps assured me that it wasn't going anywhere.  When he finally removed it--I understood why....the drain tube was 8 or more inches long!  I couldn't believe how far it was inserted.  As for the lack of drainage...make sure you're stripping your lines. Good luck tomorrow and I hope you come home drain-free!  Erin
Posts.Title: Help with drains califsun otter

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 10:43AM ehall wrote: Hi Suebee--I'm so sorry to hear your news.  I remember the fear and it was just paralyzing--but for a very short period of time.  My emotions ran the gamut....and in retrospect it wasn't long before I mustered up the energy to pull out an arsenal of fight!  Lean on these girls and do your research....I found the more information I had and knew about the more powerful I felt. Take care and know you're in our thoughts--Erin PS--I was dx last summer and wish I knew all the ladies here before now.  This has been so therapeutic for me--I hope its also helpful to others.  So many reached out to me....so I hope I'm giving back in some small way.
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 12:57PM ehall wrote: We know this is a tough time for you.  Did the nuses give you any informaion on tamoxifen.  In a nutshell, it  acts as an "anti-estrogen" in the body. Although Tamoxifen acts as an "anti-estrogen" in breast tissue, it in fact acts like estrogen in other body systems. This leads women who take Tamoxifen to experience many of the same benefits and side effects as women who undergo estrogen replacement therapy. This can include irregular periods, early menopause, weight gain/loss, etc.  Don't despair you will feel better with time.  Hugs from Atlanta! Erin
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 07:03AM ehall wrote: Hey Wren--that's great news.  I too had the same and am 4 weeks out--and feel great.  Yup...the lipo under the arms was the worse--the nerves leading to my left breast gave off some really weird sensations.  Glad to hear all is well--take care. Erin
